We originally formulate the pyramid as a sum of areas. But since it's more useful to consider volume, to have a convenient conversion to volume, we choose the height of each layer to be one. That way, the sum of area is equal to the volume. Notice that area on top of a box is equal to the volume of that box only if the height is one.

This method teaches you the right intuition on what is going on when are finding the area under the curve which is called a Riemann integral, but is just commonly called an integral. In higher Math, you would learn other methods of integration which would have a different intuition and way to construct and think about them.
@abouland9404  can you illustrate these other forms of integrals?

@tachyon_v  ​ So one is what you would see in multivariable calculus, that is we can generalize the riemann integral to higher dimensions. For functions from R2 -> R1, we would have square pillars instead of these rectangles that we "add up" and do a similar limiting process to get the riemann integral. You can then generalize this to functions Rn -> Rm. The second course by MIT, 18.02 covers this in detail.  Then there are many directions you may go for more advanced forms of integration. You can learn about some very common mathematical objects, Manifolds, and how you can do integration on them. The euclidean space Rn is one (trivial) example of a manifold, and so is a donut (or the universe for that matter). You can learn this typically in a graduate course on differentiable manifolds.  Another sort of more advanced integral is the Lebesgue integral. This is the study of "measure" (referred to as measure theory) and is covered in a graduate course in Real Analysis. In studying integrals, you have likely encountered integrals where the integral did not exist, like say a function that is 1 for rationals and 0 for irrationals, called the Dirichlet function. The Lebesgue integral fixes some issues we have seen with the Riemann integral and allows us to integrate functions we could not otherwise.  For the Dirichlet function I just described, there are far far more irrationals that rationals, so in essence, the function should be "almost" 0 right? And the Lebesgue integral for that function is in fact 0, but it is definitely not Riemann integrable. Now when it comes to functions that are Riemann integrable, it gives us the same result! That is we lose nothing, and can integrate a larger class of functions.  If you are interested in learning more, I can provide some references for books or lecture series.

Olivia Nilson Each rectangle does have the length b/n; however, he is expressing a value, x, to input into the function f (x). That is, the x value found at the second rectangle is 2b/n or b/n + b/n. The sum of the two rectangles of equal length.

fyi, for the curious: the sum of i squared with i from 1 to n is equal to n cubed divided by 3 plus n squared divided by 2 plus n divided by six.
Naveen Singh Volumes of solids can be computed using a triple integral if f (x,y,z) = 1 for a given region, Q.

It's the squeeze theorem / squeeze law. The series lies between two other things, and these two things have the same limit as n goes to infinity, so the series in the middle must have the same limit. That's the squeeze theorem.
@Bignic2008  I am not really sure if the squeeze theorem works when f(x)<g(x)<h(x) i.e. g(x) is strictly between h(x) and f(x).
there are n layers. the last layer is nth layer and the first is 1st layer.

1^2 + 2^2 + ..... (n-1)^2 + n^2 is the actual volume of the pyramid, assumed each level has a uniform height of 1. height is n is based on the previous assumption. So that when using the formula to calculate volume the pyramid we can say it is smaller than 1^2 + 2^2 + ..... (n-1)^2 + n^2

If you plug in a value for n, say 5, the the first layer is (5*5) [n*n]  then the second is [n-1]*[n-1] so when n = 5 it would be, (4)*(4). The 3rd layer is [n-2]*[n-2] ,n=5 would be, (3)*(3) and so on, until you get to (5-4)*(5-4) which be one. If you add up all the time you got the squares it would equal 5, so n base = n height. Note if the height was taken again it would be (5-5)*(5-5) which is just 0 so I think that's why he ignores it

the first (or last, depends how you look at it) term is 1 squared. That means you start with a cube whose each side is one. And you continue building it with the same kind of cubes, so the height of each one is 1. Try to draw it onto squared paper, you'll see it.
